subject: history
title: Gandhi's Early Satyagrahas (1917-1918) - Comparative Analysis
description: Champaran, Ahmedabad, and Kheda Satyagrahas - Gandhi's experiments with truth in India

introContext.title: Gandhi's Introduction to Indian Masses
introContext.description: Gandhi returned from South Africa (1915) where he developed Satyagraha technique. Advised by Gokhale to tour India for one year before entering politics. These three Satyagrahas (1917-18) were his introduction to Indian masses and testing of Satyagraha on Indian soil.
introContext.significance: These local struggles established Gandhi's leadership, refined Satyagraha method, and prepared him for all-India movements.

rows.champaran:
Tinkathia System:

‚Ä¢ European indigo planters forced peasants to grow indigo on 3/20th of land (15%)
‚Ä¢ Peasants could not grow food crops on that land
‚Ä¢ Forced to sell indigo at fixed low prices
‚Ä¢ Suffered from illegal cesses and dues
‚Ä¢ Poverty and exploitation widespread
‚Ä¢ System in place since mid-19th century
rows.ahmedabad:
Workers' Wages Dispute:

‚Ä¢ Plague in 1917 led to workers' exodus
‚Ä¢ Mill owners paid 'plague bonus' (70% wage increase) to bring workers back
‚Ä¢ As plague subsided, owners withdrew bonus
‚Ä¢ Workers demanded 50% wage increase
‚Ä¢ Owners offered only 20%
‚Ä¢ Workers went on strike
‚Ä¢ Mill owners: Ambalal Sarabhai (textile magnate)
rows.kheda:
Tax Relief Demand:

‚Ä¢ Crop failure in 1917-18 due to drought
‚Ä¢ Revenue code: taxes remitted if crop less than 25% of normal
‚Ä¢ Actual crop was 25% or less
‚Ä¢ But government refused remission
‚Ä¢ Insisted on full tax collection
‚Ä¢ Peasants unable to pay
‚Ä¢ Demanded tax suspension/reduction

rows.champaran:
‚Ä¢ Raj Kumar Shukla (local peasant) met Gandhi at Lucknow Congress (1916)
‚Ä¢ Persistently urged Gandhi to visit Champaran
‚Ä¢ Gandhi reluctantly agreed
‚Ä¢ Arrived Champaran April 1917
‚Ä¢ Was new to India, didn't know local issues deeply
‚Ä¢ Investigated personally
rows.ahmedabad:
‚Ä¢ Gandhi was living in Ahmedabad at Sabarmati Ashram
‚Ä¢ Local issue, directly approached
‚Ä¢ Anusuya Behn Sarabhai (Ambalal's sister) urged Gandhi to help workers
‚Ä¢ Gandhi's ashram philosophy emphasized labor dignity
‚Ä¢ Personal conflict: Ambalal was friend and financier of his ashram
rows.kheda:
‚Ä¢ Nearby to Ahmedabad
‚Ä¢ Local leaders (Vallabhbhai Patel, Indulal Yajnik) approached Gandhi
‚Ä¢ Gandhi familiar with Gujarat by now
‚Ä¢ Coincided with Ahmedabad strike period
‚Ä¢ Natural extension of his local work

rows.champaran:
‚Ä¢ Rajendra Prasad (later India's President)
‚Ä¢ J.B. Kripalani (Acharya Kripalani)
‚Ä¢ Braj Kishore Prasad
‚Ä¢ Mazharul Haque
‚Ä¢ Anugrah Narayan Sinha

Mostly Bihar leaders who later became national figures
rows.ahmedabad:
‚Ä¢ Anusuya Behn Sarabhai (sister of mill owner, but supported workers)
‚Ä¢ Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel
‚Ä¢ Indulal Yajnik
‚Ä¢ Shankarlal Banker

Mostly Gujarat leaders
rows.kheda:
‚Ä¢ Vallabhbhai Patel (key organizer; emerged as leader)
‚Ä¢ Indulal Yajnik
‚Ä¢ Narhari Parikh
‚Ä¢ Mohanlal Pandya
‚Ä¢ Ravi Shankar Vyas

Patel's organizational genius recognized here

rows.champaran:
Investigation & Documentation:

‚Ä¢ Gandhi defied order to leave district
‚Ä¢ Conducted detailed inquiry
‚Ä¢ Recorded 8,000+ testimonies of peasants
‚Ä¢ Documented exploitation systematically
‚Ä¢ Opened schools and dispensaries
‚Ä¢ Created awareness among peasants
‚Ä¢ Non-violent civil disobedience
‚Ä¢ Gandhi willing to go to jail
rows.ahmedabad:
Strike with Conditions:

‚Ä¢ Workers went on strike
‚Ä¢ Gandhi imposed discipline: non-violence, no coercion of non-strikers
‚Ä¢ Daily meetings for moral support
‚Ä¢ Explained workers' rights through leaflets
‚Ä¢ FAST UNTO DEATH: When strike weakening, Gandhi fasted (first political fast in India)
‚Ä¢ Fasted 3 days
‚Ä¢ Emotional pressure on mill owners (his friends)
rows.kheda:
No-Tax Campaign:

‚Ä¢ Peasants pledged not to pay taxes
‚Ä¢ Campaign for tax remission
‚Ä¢ Meetings and propaganda
‚Ä¢ Created awareness
‚Ä¢ Social boycott of those who paid
‚Ä¢ Withholding tax (civil disobedience)
‚Ä¢ Gandhi toured villages extensively

rows.champaran:
British Response:

‚Ä¢ Initially tried to force Gandhi to leave
‚Ä¢ Served notice to quit district
‚Ä¢ Gandhi refused; prepared to be arrested
‚Ä¢ Thousands gathered to support
‚Ä¢ Authorities panicked; withdrew order
‚Ä¢ Allowed him to conduct inquiry
‚Ä¢ Lt. Governor appointed official inquiry committee; Gandhi member
‚Ä¢ Accepted Gandhi's findings largely
rows.ahmedabad:
Mill Owners' Response:

‚Ä¢ Refused to negotiate initially
‚Ä¢ Adamant on their position
‚Ä¢ Gandhi's fast put moral pressure (Ambalal was friend)
‚Ä¢ Embarrassed by Gandhi's suffering
‚Ä¢ Ashram's existence depended on Ambalal's support
‚Ä¢ Finally agreed to arbitration
rows.kheda:
Government Response:

‚Ä¢ Adamant on tax collection initially
‚Ä¢ Threatened coercion and confiscation
‚Ä¢ As movement intensified, became worried
‚Ä¢ Secretly instructed officials to be lenient
‚Ä¢ Suspended tax collection from poorer peasants
‚Ä¢ Rich peasants had to pay

rows.champaran:
MAJOR SUCCESS:

‚Ä¢ Inquiry Committee findings favored peasants
‚Ä¢ Champaran Agrarian Act (1918) passed
‚Ä¢ Tinkathia system abolished completely
‚Ä¢ Indigo cultivation no longer compulsory
‚Ä¢ Peasants freed from forced indigo cultivation
‚Ä¢ Planters had to refund illegal dues (25%)
‚Ä¢ Schools and dispensaries established
rows.ahmedabad:
PARTIAL SUCCESS:

‚Ä¢ Arbitration by Prof. Anukul Chandra Banerjee
‚Ä¢ Award: 35% wage increase (between 20% and 50% demanded)
‚Ä¢ Both sides accepted
‚Ä¢ Workers got substantial raise
‚Ä¢ Textile Labour Association (TLA) formed - India's first organized non-political labor union
‚Ä¢ Established principle of collective bargaining
rows.kheda:
MORAL VICTORY:

‚Ä¢ Government suspended tax collection from poorer peasants
‚Ä¢ Rich peasants (who could pay) had to pay
‚Ä¢ Not complete success but significant concession
‚Ä¢ Demonstrated power of organized resistance
‚Ä¢ Government forced to acknowledge peasants' distress
‚Ä¢ Important psychological victory
rows.overall: All three established Gandhi's reputation and refined Satyagraha technique

rows.champaran:
For Gandhi:
‚Ä¢ First Satyagraha in India
‚Ä¢ Proved Satyagraha worked in India
‚Ä¢ Established him among peasant masses
‚Ä¢ Challenged unjust laws successfully

For India:
‚Ä¢ Showed peasants could fight exploitation
‚Ä¢ Non-violent resistance effective
‚Ä¢ Ended century-old exploitation

For Leaders:
‚Ä¢ Trained future leaders (Rajendra Prasad)

Historical:
‚Ä¢ First time nationalist leader championed peasant cause directly
rows.ahmedabad:
For Gandhi:
‚Ä¢ First experiment with fasting as political weapon
‚Ä¢ Established him as workers' champion
‚Ä¢ Moral pressure technique refined

For Workers:
‚Ä¢ First organized labor movement under Gandhi
‚Ä¢ Workers' dignity and rights established
‚Ä¢ TLA became model labor organization

For India:
‚Ä¢ Gandhian method extended to industrial workers
‚Ä¢ Non-violent labor dispute resolution

Note: Controversy over fast - seen by some as coercion on friends
rows.kheda:
For Gandhi:
‚Ä¢ Tested no-tax campaign method
‚Ä¢ Prepared for future civil disobedience
‚Ä¢ Established him in Gujarat firmly

For Patel:
‚Ä¢ Emerged as great organizer
‚Ä¢ His organizational skills recognized
‚Ä¢ Beginning of Sardar's political career

For Peasants:
‚Ä¢ Confidence to resist unjust taxation
‚Ä¢ Organized peasant power demonstrated

For India:
‚Ä¢ Template for future agrarian struggles
‚Ä¢ Tax resistance as political weapon

rows.champaran:
‚Ä¢ Non-violent resistance
‚Ä¢ Thorough investigation before action
‚Ä¢ Constructive work (schools, dispensaries)
‚Ä¢ Willingness to face arrest
‚Ä¢ Mass mobilization
‚Ä¢ Moral force over physical force
‚Ä¢ Satyagraha = holding firmly to truth
rows.ahmedabad:
‚Ä¢ Fasting as moral pressure
‚Ä¢ Non-violence even in strikes
‚Ä¢ Discipline among protesters
‚Ä¢ No coercion of opponents/non-participants
‚Ä¢ Arbitration preferred over confrontation
‚Ä¢ Building permanent organization (TLA)
‚Ä¢ Personal suffering to move hearts
rows.kheda:
‚Ä¢ Civil disobedience (tax refusal)
‚Ä¢ Extensive grassroots organization
‚Ä¢ Social pressure and unity
‚Ä¢ Withstanding government coercion
‚Ä¢ Compromise when necessary
‚Ä¢ Practical approach (rich paid, poor exempted)
‚Ä¢ Village-level mobilization

rows.champaran:
‚Ä¢ Local issue; limited geographic spread
‚Ä¢ Did not address broader peasant exploitation
‚Ä¢ Compromise: only 25% refund, not full
‚Ä¢ Upper-caste peasants benefited more
‚Ä¢ Gandhi still testing methods
rows.ahmedabad:
‚Ä¢ Benefited industrial workers only
‚Ä¢ Gandhi's fast controversial (pressure on friends)
‚Ä¢ Divided opinion among colleagues
‚Ä¢ Not fully voluntary settlement (pressure)
‚Ä¢ Limited to one mill, one city
rows.kheda:
‚Ä¢ Partial success; rich had to pay
‚Ä¢ Not all peasants benefited equally
‚Ä¢ Government concession grudging, not policy change
‚Ä¢ Did not address root cause of agrarian distress
‚Ä¢ Limited to one district

rows.champaran:
For Non-Cooperation Movement (1920):

‚Ä¢ Investigation & documentation crucial
‚Ä¢ Constructive work alongside resistance
‚Ä¢ Peasant base can be mobilized
‚Ä¢ British vulnerable to moral pressure
‚Ä¢ Non-violence works if disciplined
rows.ahmedabad:
For Future Struggles:

‚Ä¢ Fasting effective but must be used judiciously
‚Ä¢ Workers can be organized non-violently
‚Ä¢ Arbitration better than confrontation
‚Ä¢ Permanent organizations needed (led to TLA, later AITUC influence)
‚Ä¢ Also taught Gandhi limits of using personal relationships
rows.kheda:
For Civil Disobedience (1930):

‚Ä¢ No-tax campaign can be powerful weapon
‚Ä¢ But needs strong organization
‚Ä¢ Peasant unity crucial
‚Ä¢ Government forced to negotiate
‚Ä¢ Template for future Salt Satyagraha and CDM

additionalInfo.title: Common Features & Overall Assessment

commonFeatures.detail: All were local struggles, not all-India movements
All addressed economic exploitation of common people
All established Gandhi's leadership and refined his methods
All served as training for future national leaders

additionalInfo.significance: These three struggles were Gandhi's 'laboratory experiments' with Satyagraha in India. They established his mass contact, refined his methods, trained future leaders, and prepared ground for all-India movements (Non-Cooperation 1920, Civil Disobedience 1930).
additionalInfo.examTip: Remember 'CPK' (Champaran-Peasants-Indigo; Ahmedabad-Textile workers-Wages; Kheda-Peasants-Tax). Also remember associates: Champaran-Rajendra Prasad; Ahmedabad-Anusuya Behn; Kheda-Vallabhbhai Patel.
